I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During an Asian Development Bank (ADB) power sector reconnaissance mission in 
June 2005, the Government of the Fiji Islands requested ADB’s assistance in developing the 
power  sector.  Following  a  request  for  technical  assistance  (TA)  by  the  Government  in 
December 2005 to prepare a renewable power sector development project, an ADB fact-finding 
mission  visited  the  Fiji  Islands  from  12  to  16 December  2005.  The  mission  reached  an 
understanding with the Government and the Fiji Electricity Authority (FEA) on the objectives, 
scope, cost and financing, and implementation arrangements, and the consultants’ outline terms 
of reference for the TA.1 The concept paper for the proposed TA was approved on 23 December 
2005. The TA will support the development of a renewable least-cost expansion plan to diversify 
energy resources and meet expected future load growth. The design and monitoring framework 
is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The economic performance of the Fiji Islands has been mixed. Exceptionally high growth 
of 9% in gross domestic product (GDP) in 1999 was followed by a sharp economic contraction 
as a result of the military coup in 2000. But economic growth has recovered since then, mainly 
because of an increase in construction activities and tourism. Annual economic growth has 
averaged about 3% over the last 5 years. Continued investments in several sectors are key, to 
diversify the production base and make the country less vulnerable to adverse global market 
events, create employment opportunities, and sustain economic growth and poverty reduction. 
 
3.  FEA, a corporate utility fully owned by the Government, is responsible for grid supply in 
the Fiji Islands. With the completion of the rural electrification program in 2004, FEA provides 
electricity services to about 125,000 consumers, or about half of the population, on the two main 
islands of Vanua Levu and Viti Levu and on the smaller island of Ovalau. Electricity demand has 
been growing at 5% yearly in the last 5 years and is expected to continue to grow faster than 
GDP in the medium term. This growth in demand is driven mainly by the commercial sectors.  
 
4.  The total installed capacity of the FEA system is 186 megawatts (MW), including about 
70 MW of diesel generation. Of the 90 MW of hydropower generation, 80 MW is from the 
Monasavu hydropower scheme. FEA is now undertaking a small pilot solar generation project2 
and  pilot  projects involving  vegetable  oil  mixtures  in  place  of  diesel  generation.  FEA  also 
supplements its capacity from three independent power producers and has entered into a joint 
venture with the private sector for 6 MW and 2.8 MW hydropower schemes. In addition, a 10 
MW wind power plant will be commissioned in 2006.  
 
5.  Ensuring that generation, transmission, and distribution capacity is enough to meet 
electricity demand is a key challenge facing the power sector. To meet growing demand and 
replace obsolete diesel generators, FEA installed 41 MW of diesel capacity in 2004–2005. In 
2002, about 15% of FEA’s total costs went to fuel costs. By 2004, with global fuel prices 
increasing and FEA having to meet the growing demand through diesel generation, fuel costs 
had  risen  to  38%  of  total  costs.  Tariffs  were  increased.  That  same  year,  the  Commerce 
Commission, which regulates tariffs, approved a cumulative tariff increase of 9.9% for domestic 
consumers and 20% for nondomestic consumers in 2005–2007. To protect poor consumers 
from rising fuel prices, the Government introduced a lifeline tariff. Given the sharp fluctuations in

fuel prices on the world markets, the generation mix must improve to make the cost of supply of 
electricity more predictable. 
 
6.  The  Government’s  Strategic  Development  Plan  for  2003–2005  looks  forward  to  a 
resource-efficient, cost-effective, and environmentally sustainable energy sector. To this end, 
FEA has embarked on a strategy to diversify its generation sources and promote clean and 
renewable energy. This will reduce the exposure of FEA, and ultimately the consumers, to 
foreign exchange risks and global fuel price hikes.   
 
7.  FEA’s corporate plan makes explicit its commitment to the development of renewable 
energy resources. It has carried out a comprehensive long-term planning study on renewable 
generation, transmission, and distribution upgrades, to meet the growing demand, promote 
renewable  energy  resources,  and  replace  obsolete  diesel  generation.  The  total  financing 
requirements for 2005–2010 are estimated at $300 million, including FEA’s own investments 
and participation by the private sector. 
 
8.  The Government’s and FEA’s commitment to renewable energy is consistent with the 
need to adapt to climate change and variability (CCV). The effects of climate change are being 
felt through climate extremes such as unusually intense or unseasonal cyclones, flooding, 
droughts, and other natural phenomena. Scientific evidence indicates that some extreme events 
will  become  more  frequent  or  intensify  in  the  decades  to  come.  Countries  in  the  Pacific, 
including the Fiji Islands, are vulnerable to CCV, according to the United Nations Framework 
Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). The country remains vulnerable to future changes 
in the regional climate that could increase the risks and reduce the benefits of economic 
development.  Therefore,  it  must  adapt  to  become  less  vulnerable.  Adaptation  will  mean 
reducing  both  present  and  future  risks  related  to  CCV  by  “climate-proofing”  the  proposed 
projects to withstand extreme climate events. In this way, the Fiji Islands will become more 
resilient to the effects of CCV and the Project will more likely be sustainable. 
 
9.  The Kyoto Protocol requires developed countries to reduce their carbon emissions from 
1990 levels by 5.2% by 2008–2012. Under its flexible mechanisms, industrialized countries that 
are obliged to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions can purchase some of those reductions 
in developing countries or transition economies in exchange for clean technology and additional 
financing. Developing countries thus gain an opportunity to participate in a growing carbon 
market.  Flexible  market  mechanisms  like  the  clean  development  mechanism  (CDM)  are 
available.  The  CDM  generates  advantages  for  all  participants,  as  the  achieved  emission 
reduction is measured and credited toward the emission commitments of the investing countries. 
Investment  funding  in  support  of  renewable  energy  sources  and  energy  efficiency  can  be 
mobilized this way for countries like the Fiji Islands.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The TA supports FEA’s power sector investment program by assisting in the preparation 
of a least-cost expansion program for renewable and indigenous resources, and the upgrading 
of the transmission and distribution networks to enable FEA to provide end-consumers with 
enough, reliable electricity services. The investment program will help the country and FEA, and 
ultimately end-consumers, to reduce exposure to global fuel prices by promoting indigenous and 
renewable energy resources.

3
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA activities will cover the following key areas: (i) review and sensitivity analysis of 
FEA’s prioritized least-cost power sector expansion program to meet low-, base-, and high-
demand  forecasts;  (ii)  review  of  FEA’s  engineering  feasibility  studies  of  prioritized  core 
subprojects; (iii) assessment and projection of FEA’s financial performance; (iv) financial and 
economic analyses of the investment program, including risk analysis; (v) compliance with 
ADB’s safeguard policies; (vi) climate-proofing analysis of the proposed project; and (vii) CDM 
screening of FEA’s investment program.  
 
12.  The review of the least-cost power expansion program will take into account demand 
forecasts, generation alternatives, and the appropriate generation mix. Two FEA staff members 
will be trained in demand forecasting. Existing feasibility studies of prioritized core subprojects 
will be reviewed, and procurement arrangements, including contract packages and a project 
implementation schedule, will be prepared.  
 
13.  Since individual subprojects—which will not yield benefits if considered singly—are part 
of the power sector expansion program, a time-slice approach will be used in the economic and 
financial  analyses  of  the  Project.  A  distribution  analysis  will  be  conducted  to  assess  the 
distribution of net benefits and cross-subsidies among key stakeholders. Risks and the effects 
of various delays in generation plants on financial and economic results will be analyzed. FEA’s 
financial  performance  will  be  subjected  to  financial  due  diligence  and  projections,  and 
appropriate financial performance measures will be set.  
14.  FEA, through its land department, has identified landowners and has obtained their 
agreement  to  the  investigation  activities  for  the  proposed  core  subprojects.  To  ensure 
compliance with ADB’s safeguard polices on the environment, involuntary resettlement, and 
indigenous peoples, the TA will review FEA’s existing work and the Government’s procedures 
and, if necessary, conduct supplementary detailed field surveys for core subprojects, including 
access roads. The surveys will cover planned generation sites, the alignment of transmission 
lines  and  sites  of  substations  and  power  stations,  and  any  necessary  access  roads.  The 
surveys will be made to identify environmental effects and to prepare a full inventory of all land 
and other affected assets and a socioeconomic assessment of project-affected households. All 
information will be gender-disaggregated. A resettlement plan conforming to ADB’s policies will 
be prepared for core subprojects, and a resettlement framework will be drawn up to guide the 
preparation of subprojects under the loan. The resettlement plan will include the necessary 
compensation  and  income  restoration  measures;  the  most  suitable  implementation 
arrangements; public information, disclosure, and grievance procedures; and the cost of the 
compensation and income restoration measures. The initial poverty and social analysis is in 
Appendix 2. 
 
15.  FEA has done substantial work in the environmental assessment of selected subprojects. 
The Department of Energy has approved the environmental assessment of one of the proposed 
core subprojects. The TA will review this work and prepare an initial environmental examination, 
according to ADB’s guidelines for environmental assessment for sector loans. Subprojects will 
be  assessed  according  to  ADB’s  guidelines  and  environmental  assessment,  and  review 
procedures, including criteria for subproject selection, will be established for subprojects to be 
identified under the loan. The environmental assessment will review and evaluate the following: 
(i) the environmental soundness of the concept, approach, and prospective sites of the core 
subprojects; (ii) major environmental concerns and benefits; and (iii) mitigation measures and a 
monitoring plan. Any adverse effects identified will be incorporated into the project design and

4   
considered  in  the  implementation.  The  cost  of  mitigation  measures  and  the  associated 
environmental management and monitoring plan will be estimated, and the estimates will be part 
of  the project cost estimates. The environmental assessment and the resulting environmental 
management plans will be aimed at preventing, reducing, or relieving adverse effects on the 
environment and the third parties. Field visits will be made to collect data and local interest 
groups will be consulted so that their views and concerns are considered in the project design.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at US$930,000, comprising US$557,000 in foreign 
exchange and US$373,000 equivalent in local currency. The Government has requested ADB 
to finance US$650,000, comprising the entire foreign exchange cost and a portion of the local 
currency cost amounting to US$93,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis 
from  ADB’s  TA  funding  program.  The  Government  will  finance  the remaining US$280,000 
equivalent in local currency through in-kind contributions from FEA. Government counterpart 
funds will cover the costs associated with office accommodation and facilities and counterpart 
staff. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. The Government has 
been informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The  Ministry  of  Works  and  Energy,  through  its  Department  of  Energy,  will  be  the 
Executing Agency. It has designated FEA as the Implementing Agency for the TA. Before 
fielding the consultants, FEA has agreed to nominate counterpart staff with adequate capacity in 
engineering  and  power  system  planning,  finance,  environment,  and  social  areas.  FEA  will 
assign  appropriate  counterpart  staff  for  field  visits.  It  will  also  provide  all  the  necessary 
assistance to the TA consultants in coordinating with other government ministries and agencies, 
and in obtaining the necessary data and documentation, including high-quality detailed maps for 
the routing of transmission lines, and for the locations of substations and generation plants.  
 
18.  The TA will require about 19 person-months of international and 5 person-months of 
domestic consulting services. It will be implemented over an 8-month period from February to 
September 2006. Appendix 4 gives outline terms of reference for the consultants. At the start of 
TA implementation, a tripartite meeting will be held to discuss the work to be done by the 
consultants and ADB’s requirements related to resettlement. Tripartite meetings at which FEA 
and the consultants will be present will also be held after the interim and draft final reports are 
submitted. The environment, resettlement, and social specialists will be fielded once the core 
subprojects have been identified. The consultants will prepare status reports on their specific 
scope of work, highlighting issues that could be critical to the timely completion of the TA. The 
consultants will arrange for on-the-job training for relevant FEA staff members.  
 
19.  The  consultants  will  be  selected  individually  to  ensure  that  key  loan  processing 
deadlines are met and that investments are made on time. For effective coordination, a project 
coordinator will be hired to assist ADB in coordinating the inputs of the individual experts. The 
consultants will be hired by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the hiring of domestic consultants. Computer 
software will be procured according to arrangements acceptable to ADB and turned over to FEA 
after the TA.

5
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of US$650,000 on a grant basis 
to the Government of the Fiji Islands for preparing the Renewable Power Sector Development 
Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Fiji Islands: 
Diversification of economic growth and foreign and local investments are critical to sustainable economic growth and 
increased employment opportunities. Reliable power supply is important for continued diversification of the production 
base, which will bring about employment and increase productivity in the agriculture and service sectors. 
 
The country is a small open economy, highly vulnerable to global energy prices. With recent hikes in energy prices, 
the pressure to increase power tariffs has intensified. The poor spend more of their income on fuel and energy, 
including electricity, than the nonpoor. The fiscal space to support subsidies to the poor is very limited. Diversification 
of generation toward indigenous and renewable energy resources will help reduce the pressure on tariff increases in 
the longer term, possibly avoid the opportunity cost of fiscal expenditure on power subsidies, and make power more 
affordable to the poor.  
 
The increased use of indigenous resources will also reduce the impact of increased energy prices on the trade 
balance and thus help improve external balances and economic growth.  
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? The poverty analysis will be an integral part of the social and participatory 
analysis and will focus on vulnerability, particularly to fuel and energy prices. In addition, the Fiji Electricity Authority’s 
(FEA’s) disaggregated consumer base data, tariff blocks, and cross-subsidies will undergo economic and financial 
analyses. A distribution analysis of net benefits and subsidies to key stakeholders will be conducted.  
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
 
Consultations with affected people have been undertaken by FEA. A stakeholder analysis will be an integral part of the 
economic (distributional), social, and resettlement assessments. The stakeholder analysis under the economic and 
social assessments will be mainly descriptive and will assess the distribution of expected costs and benefits. For 
transmission line routings, information will need to be gathered and people and local communities in affected areas 
will need to be consulted. 
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
 
The project preparatory technical assistance (TA) will design a full participation strategy to be undertaken before and 
during the construction. The strategy will include the design of public information disclosure, compensation and 
resettlement, and grievance procedures.  
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women:

including  women,  from  benefiting  from  the  Project.  If  women  are  adversely  affected  during  resettlement,  the 
resettlement plan will include ways to mitigate these adverse effects. All data collected will be gender-disaggregated.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Project Coordination and Procurement (international, 3.0 person-months) 
 
1.  The consultant will assist the Asian Development Bank (ADB) task officer in managing and 
coordinating the consultant specialists’ work to prepare a proposed sector loan in support of the 
power sector expansion program of the Fiji Electricity Authority (FEA). He/She will be actively 
involved, to ensure the quality of implementation arrangements, procurement, and system planning. 
The consultant will (i) Assist and provide ongoing support to the ADB task officer in managing the 
work of the various consultant specialists’ due-diligence work in preparing the proposed power 
sector loan and assist with tripartite meetings with the consultants, FEA, and ADB. (ii) Interact with 
FEA’s  management  and  engineering  departments  and  guide  the  power  system  planner  in 
preparing  the  least-cost  power  sector  expansion  program.  (iii)  Coordinate  the  resettlement, 
environment, and system planning to ensure timely delivery and consistency of work. (iv) Assist in 
the preparation of the report and recommendation of the president (RRP). (v) Guide the power 
system planner in preparing detailed lists of materials, equipment, and works necessary for the 
prioritized  core  subprojects,  and  estimate  their  costs,  classified  into  foreign  and  local  cost 
components. (vi) Outline the scope of work of the implementation consultants and the procurement 
arrangements,  including  contract  packaging,  and  prepare  a  project  implementation  schedule. 
(vii) Prepare templates for subproject analysis and train relevant FEA staff to prepare the relevant 
documentation for submission to ADB. (viii) Review FEA’s institutional capacity for its operation 
and  project  implementation,  and  assess  the  requirements  for  specific  assistance  in  capacity 
building. 
 
B.  Power System Planning (international, 3.0 person months) 
 
2.  The consultant will do the following: (i) Review FEA’s current generation mix, power system 
expansion plan, and method of prioritizing generation projects to meet expected demand. (ii) Using 
appropriate generation and system planning tools and load flow analysis, prepare (a) an optimized 
least-cost  expansion  plan  over  an  investment  period  of  5–7  years,  including  generation, 
transmission, and distribution; and (b) a justification for the expansion plan. Assess the average 
cost of supply against feasible alternatives. The least-cost expansion plan will take into account the 
Government’s energy sector policy and FEA’s corporate plan, as well as the costs associated with 
social  and  environment  mitigation  measures.  (iii)  In  collaboration  with  the  economic  analyst, 
identify risks and analyze the effects of delays on the least-cost expansion plan and the ability to 
meet forecast demand. (iv) On the basis of the optimized least-cost expansion plan and load flow 
analysis,  prioritize  generation  projects  and  appropriate  grid  system  expansion.  Prepare  a 
justification for prioritized subprojects. (v) Prepare or review existing pre-feasibility studies for a first 
batch of prioritized subprojects. Find out if the subprojects indeed represent the least-cost solution 
for  the  expansion  of  the  system  to  meet  the  expected  load  growth.  Identify  and  prepare  a 
summarized subproject profile containing the major indicative scope of work of each subproject. 
(vi) Prepare selection criteria for the engineering least-cost design of subprojects to be identified 
and included under the project implementation. This task will include identifying and providing 
outline assessments for the additional subprojects needed to make up the loan and listing the 
information required to make such assessments as may be later performed by FEA under the 
proposed sector loan. (vii) In cooperation with the project coordinator, prepare detailed lists of 
materials, equipment, and works necessary for the prioritized core subprojects to be funded, and 
estimate their costs, classified into foreign and local cost components. (viii) In collaboration with the 
financial analyst, prepare cost estimates for the proposed sector project, classified into foreign and 
local costs. (ix) Assist the project coordinator in outlining project implementation and procurement 
arrangements,  including  contract  packaging,  and  prepare  a  project  implementation  schedule. 
(x) Assist in the preparation of templates for subproject analysis and train relevant FEA staff to

12  Appendix 4 
 
prepare the relevant documentation for submission to ADB. (xi) Prepare the scope of work and 
terms of reference for the implementation consultants. 
 
C.  Financial Analysis (international, 3.0 person-months) 
 
3.  The consultant will prepare a financial analysis of FEA’s proposed investment plan as 
follows:  (i)  Carry  out  in-depth  financial  analysis  of  the  proposed  investment  plan,  including 
calculation of the financial internal rate of return (FIRR) and weighted average cost of capital 
(WACC), taking into account all the financial costs and benefits. (ii) Identify all risks to investment 
plan  revenue  and  costs,  and  conduct  relevant  sensitivity  analysis  on  the  financial  results. 
(iii) Prepare a detailed financing plan for the investment plan, including proposed ADB lending, any 
prospective  cofinancing  (including  investment  in  a  clean  development  mechanism),  and 
appropriate counterpart funds for local currency expenditures. (iv) Review FEA’s inter-company 
transfer pricing and bulk tariff structure to determine whether the true cost of supply is being 
adequately recovered or subsidized through a transparent mechanism, and identify the specific 
sources and projection of revenue that will ensure the financial viability of the investment plan, 
taking into account the reduction of technical line losses and any improvements in operational 
efficiency.  (v) Prepare  a  supplementary  appendix  and  appendix  to  the  RRP  for  the  financial 
analysis of the investment plan.  
 
4.  The consultant will assess FEA’s financial performance as follows: (i) Review the most 
current audited or unaudited financial statements of FEA to assess historical financial performance, 
retail  tariff  levels,  capital  structure,  and  sufficient  generation  of  internal  funds  to  ensure 
sustainability of ongoing operations (i.e., ability to self-finance a reasonable percentage of capital 
expenditures and service existing debt). (ii) Review recent audited or unaudited project accounts of 
FEA  to  determine  proper  accounting  and  cost  control.  (iii)  Recommend  appropriate  financial 
performance measures or ratios for FEA and assess compliance with such measures or ratios in 
pro  forma  statements.  (iv)  Assist  counterparts  in  designing  project  fund  flow  mechanisms. 
(v) Prepare a supplementary appendix and appendix to the RRP briefly summarizing past historical 
and  projected  financial  performance.  The  documents  will  include  10-year  pro  forma  financial 
statements (balance sheet, income statement, statement of cash flows) for FEA. (vi) Assess FEA’s 
financial management capabilities and make recommendations for the institutional strengthening of 
financial  management  along  with  a  recommended  time-bound  implementation  schedule. 
(vii) Review the latest developments in enhancing private sector participation and regulatory reform 
in the power sector. 
 
D.  Economic Analysis (international, 2.5 person-months) 
 
5.  The  consultant  will  (i)  Review  FEA’s  demand  forecasts  and  prepare  demand  forecast 
scenarios by major consumer category and key geographical area corresponding to high, low, and 
base cases. The demand forecasts will include forecasts of seasonal and monthly peak demand by 
consumer category. (ii) Prepare an MS Excel–based forecasting program tailored to FEA’s needs 
(expansion program and subproject analysis) and provide on-the-job training to two FEA staff in 
updating  demand  forecasts,  including  monthly  and  seasonal  peak  demands.  (iii)  In  close 
collaboration with the system planner, prepare least-cost alternatives for system expansion and 
calculate  the  cost  of  supply  under  the  different  demand  growth  scenarios.  (iv)  Prepare  an 
economic analysis of the proposed expansion program consistent with the financial analysis, and 
provide  an  analysis  of  the  distribution  of  the  net  benefits  (and  cross-subsidies)  across  key 
beneficiaries,  including  FEA,  investors,  lenders,  government,  and  key  consumer  categories. 
(v) Identify risks and analyze the effects of delays on the least-cost expansion plan and the ability 
to meet forecast demands. Conduct sensitivity analysis on the economic results and assess the

Appendix 4   13
implications  for  the  distribution  of  net  benefits.  (vi)  Conduct  a  risk analysis  of  key  risks  and 
assumptions using @Risk or other similar programs. 
 
E.  Environmental  Assessment  (international,  2.5  person-months;  domestic,  3.5  person-
months).  
 
6.  In accordance with the guidelines for sector loans, the consultants will: (i) Gather secondary 
data on the physical environment, ecological resources, and quality-of-life values of the candidate 
core subproject areas and other affected areas, and primary data for some ecologically sensitive 
issues. (ii) Undertake field surveys of proposed core subprojects to collect information on the 
environmental  conditions  and  areas  that  will  be  used  as  temporary  storage  of  construction 
materials, construction equipment, temporary offices, and camps. (iii) Assess the environmental 
impact of the Project including its physical, biological, sociocultural, and economic aspects, and 
both direct and indirect impact during pre-construction, construction, and operation, including those 
due to induced economic activity in the foreseeable future, and their cumulative impact. (iv) Assess 
the associated environmental impact of the Project. (vi) Assess the environmental benefits from the 
use of renewable energy resources. (vi) Recommend: (a) measures to safeguard the environment 
during the pre-construction, construction, and operational phases of the Project; (b) mitigation 
measures and the monitoring program, including cost implications, and an institutional setup for the 
program; and (c) the agencies that should be responsible for environmental monitoring during 
project implementation. (vi) Undertake sector impact assessment and prepare an environmental 
assessment and review procedure (EARP) for the sector project that will describe the overall 
procedures for environmental assessment and review of subprojects, including selection criteria for 
the  follow-up  subprojects,  following  ADB  guidelines  and  formats.  (vii)  Prepare  (a)  an  initial 
environmental examination (IEE) report, including an environmental management and monitoring 
plan (EMP) and an executive summary, for each core subproject; (b) an overall summary initial 
environmental  examination  (SIEE)  incorporating  the  findings  of  the  IEE  of  core  subprojects, 
identifying  the  generic  environmental  impact  of  the  sector  loan  project  (direct,  indirect,  and 
cumulative impact of all subprojects) and the EMP; (c) environmental assessment and review 
procedure  for  the  sector  project;  and,  (d)  an  EIA  report  if  the  IEE  recommends  a  detailed 
environmental impact assessment (EIA). (viii) If any core subprojects will encroach close to or into 
environmentally  sensitive  areas,  the  consultants  will  also  (a)  gather  secondary  data  on  the 
ecological functions of the areas, including the legal status of the areas at the local, national, and 
international  levels;  (b)  undertake  field  surveys  to  portray  the  condition  of  the  areas,  giving 
information on the relation between the ecological function of the whole protected area and the 
area to be affected by the proposed core subproject, and including vegetation analysis and an 
inventory of wildlife species and a desk analysis of their sensitivity to disturbances; (c) predict and 
assess the potential impact of the proposed project on the protected area or areas with ecological 
significance; (d) prepare mitigation measures and costs; and (d) incorporate the findings, including 
the proposed EMP, in the main IEE/SIEE. (ix) Undertake consultations with the affected people 
and other stakeholders in the project area during the environmental assessment to get their 
perceptions of the Project and their acceptance, and document the public consultations in a table 
indicating  dates,  agencies/institutions,  participants,  major  issues  discussed,  and  conclusions. 
(x) Assess  the  institutional  capacity  of  FEA  and  other  concerned  agencies  to  implement  the 
proposed EMP and, if necessary, propose the necessary training to enable FEA to implement the 
EMP. (xi) Assist the FEA in securing environmental clearance certificates for each core subproject 
as  required  by  the  Government,  and  prepare  the  necessary  information  to  comply  with  the 
guidelines of ADB and the Government.  
 
F.  Clean  Development  Mechanism  (CDM)  Specialist  (international,  1.5  person-months; 
domestic, 1.5 person-months)

14  Appendix 4 
 
7.  The consultant will do the following: 
 (i)  (a) Review the energy development plans and climate change policies, and the 
associated institutional and regulatory framework, of the country with respect to the 
role and scope for promoting CDM projects; (b) collect technical information on the 
proposed core subprojects, e.g., need for them, size and magnitude, and eligibility 
for CDM financing; and (c) gain familiarity with ADB’s CDM facility.1  
(ii)  Prepare (a) the CDM project design document (PDD)2 for the core subprojects; 
(b) draft CDM PDDs for the small-scale noncore subprojects; (c) a framework PDD 
for noncore subprojects that do not meet the specifications of small-scale CDM 
projects according to the United Nations Framework on Climate Change (UNFCCC) 
agreed definition for small-scale CDM projects; and (d) a report on developments in 
the emission reduction market including factors that may influence the price for 
emission reduction credits and the existing players in the market, and assess the 
potential market for emission reduction credits from the Project to enable FEA to 
determine its strategy for the sale of emission reduction credits; (e) develop FEA’s 
capacity  to  familiarize  itself  with  the  requirements  for  a  CDM  project  and  the 
necessary documentation, and to provide information on the market for emission 
reduction; (f) assist FEA in developing the PDD for the core subprojects included in 
the Project, preparing for each small-scale CDM (less than 15 MW capacity) the 
complete document that will meet all the requirements of the “Simplified Project 
Design  Document  for  Small-Scale  Project  Activities,”  in  a  format  to  clear  the 
necessary validation process; and (g) assist FEA in marketing its emission reduction 
credits from the subprojects under CDM and building its in-house capacity to identify 
and develop similar CDM projects.  
 
G.  Climate Change Adaptation Analysis (international, 1.0 person-month)  
 
8.  The  consultant  will  (i)  Collect  past  and  present  climatic  data  (particularly  rainfall, 
temperature, wind, and sea levels) and on the basis of the data prepare a country climate risk 
profile showing climate conditions and the likelihood of future changes in climate conditions and 
the evidence of extreme weather events (particularly cyclone and extreme rainfall/drought). Use 
available climate modeling tools as far as possible in simulating the future climate conditions. 
(ii) On the basis of the climatic data and projections of likely future climatic conditions, assess 
climate-related risks under the Project, and identify a range of adaptation options that may be 
considered  in  mainstreaming  adaptation  through  risk  reduction.  Recommend  adaptation 
interventions that reflect least-cost, least-impact, and greatest overall benefit in the context of the 
biophysical, social, cultural, and economic dimensions of the Project. (iii) In coordination with FEA, 
the consultants’ team leader, and other members of the consulting team (particularly the power 
system planner and the economic analyst), and using the model presented in the ADB report 
Climate Proofing: A Risk-based approach to Adaptation, incorporate adaptation to climate change 
into the project design, including costing of the adaptation measures. (iv) Explore the availability of 
a climate change adaptation fund, and assist FEA in gaining access to the fund for the core 
subproject. 
 
H.  Stakeholder Participation, Resettlement, and Social Analysis (international, 2.5 person-
months; domestic, 2.0 person-months) 
 
9.  The consultant will do the following in accordance with the guidelines for sector loans: 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2003. Clean Development Mechanism Facility. Manila 
2  The “Simplified Project Design Document for Small-Scale CDM Project Activities” (SSC-PDD) available on the 
UNFCCC CDM site http://cdm.unfccc.int/Reference/Documents lists the requirements for the PDD for small-scale 
CDM projects.

Appendix 4   15
(i)  Assess the institutional capacity and arrangements of FEA and other concerned 
agencies to meet the resettlement requirements for sector loans of the ADB to plan, 
manage, implement, finance, and monitor effective land acquisition, compensation, 
resettlement, and rehabilitation. Propose measures that may need to be enhanced 
to effectively implement resettlement requirements.  
(ii)  For core subprojects: (a) Assess the need to acquire land, (re)establish right-of-way, 
and options to avoid or minimize involuntary resettlement. If involuntary resettlement 
effects are identified, develop subproject resettlement plans for core subprojects to 
address any full or partial, permanent or temporary, loss of housing, land, or income 
from any affected business establishment, and impact on non-titled and vulnerable 
people.  (b)  Conduct  a  baseline  socioeconomic  survey  reflecting  socioeconomic 
profiles,  including  gender  and  local  ethnic  minorities,  of  the  project-affected 
communities. (c) On the basis of the results of the survey and inventory of land, 
identify compensation and rehabilitation options, develop livelihood rehabilitation 
and improvement programs for affected persons, and prepare an entitlement matrix 
covering compensation and other assistance for all types of impact, to achieve full 
replacement for lost assets, income, and livelihoods. (d) Conduct a replacement 
cost survey to determine unit replacement costs of assets lost and ensure that 
compensation  standards  are  based  on  replacement  value.  (e)  Prepare  an 
entitlement matrix listing all the likely effects of both permanent and temporary land 
acquisition.  (f)  Prepare  a  detailed  budget  with  unit  cost  estimates  based  on 
replacement  costs  for  lost  assets,  implementation  schedules,  management 
arrangements,  and  arrangements  for  internal  and  external  monitoring  and 
evaluation.  (g)  Prepare  a  grievance  mechanism  and  appeal  procedures,  and 
mechanisms for disclosing the core project resettlement plan to affected persons, 
for disclosing the final subproject resettlement plan to affected persons, and for 
disclosing the resettlement plans and framework on ADB’s Web site. (h) Assist the 
Executing Agency in documenting consultations conducted with the affected people 
and other stakeholders in each core subproject area. (i) Develop an implementation 
schedule  showing  how  activities  will  be  scheduled,  with  time-bound  actions  in 
coordination with the civil works. 
(iii)  For noncore subprojects: develop a resettlement framework in accordance with 
ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy and Operations Manual F2 on Involuntary 
Resettlement, The resettlement framework will guide the preparation of resettlement 
plans for noncore subprojects. 
(iv)  In preparing the resettlement framework and core subproject resettlement plans, 
review  government  policies  and  guidelines/procedures  for  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement,  identify  discrepancies  between  the  Government’s  and  ADB’s 
Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy  requirements  and  procedures,  and  propose 
measures to bridge the gap between ADB’s and the Government’s policies. 
(v)  Prepare a monitoring and reporting program for resettlement (to be implemented by 
FEA), including implementation arrangements and cost estimates, to monitor the 
implementation of mitigating measures and their impact on affected people. 
(vi)  Undertake social analysis to determine if ethnic minority people are disadvantaged 
or vulnerable because of their social or cultural identity. If ethnic minority people are 
disadvantaged, prepare a time-bound ethnic minority development plan (EMDP), 
including specific measures and approaches to be taken to address the concerns of 
ethnic minority people, with full stakeholder participation and in accordance with 
   
ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples.
